title: Renjie Lu
text:
This is a Renjie Lu website.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.
Welcome to my academic world.
Assignment 1: Here is the link to the Movie Survey for EPPS 6302: https://utdallas.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_2iyCZHeebA2Vv4W

Setting up



Download the Movie_Rental_Survey.qsf file from class GitHub (https://github.com/datageneration/datamethods) under survey
Click on the Movie_Rental_Survey.qsf



Right click the Raw button, save link as/download file as
Save it to target folder on your local drive (e.g. Users/username/epps6302 | c:\epps6302\ )



Login to Qualtrics
Open a browser and visit UT Dallas Qualtrics site: https://utdallas.qualtrics.com



Login using NetID
Create a Survey
Menu→Projects→ Click “Create a new project” button
Choose “Survey” and name the project (e.g. EPPS6302)
Under “How do you want to start your survey?”, choose “Import a QSF file”
use Movie survey as name



Analyze survey:



How is the survey structured?

Introduction: The survey begins with an introduction that explains its purpose and why the respondent’s input is important. Informed Consent: In some surveys, especially those involving sensitive or personal information, an informed consent section may be included. Main Survey Questions: These are the core questions of the survey that are designed to gather the specific information or opinions you are interested in. Demographic Questions: Surveys often start with demographic questions to collect basic information about the respondents, such as age, gender, location, occupation, education level, and other relevant characteristics.

What is the questionnaire composed of?

Multiple-Choice Questions: Respondents choose from a list of predefined options. These options can be single-select (choose one) or multiple-select (choose multiple).
Likert Scale Questions: These questions ask respondents to rate their agreement, satisfaction, or preference on a scale (e.g., strongly agree, agree, neutral, disagree, strongly disagree).
Open-Ended Questions: These questions allow respondents to provide free-text responses in their own words. They are valuable for collecting qualitative data and insights.
Ranking Questions: Respondents are asked to rank items or options in order of preference or importance.

How are the questions ordered? Started with the main questions first, then move on the demographic questions.
Check out the Import from Library option to consider importing:a. US race question (under Demographics→US demographics)b. US Zip code question



Change the Look and Feel (paint roller icon on left menu) to select UT Dallas theme
Use Skip Logic in Q4, if answer is NO, skip to the question Q7 “Do you feel comfortable purchasing software over the internet?”
Apply Validation to every question (Force Response)
Insert Page break to save respondents from scrolling down the screen.
What can be done to improve respondent’s experience?

Clear and Concise Language: Use clear and easily understandable language in your questions and instructions. Avoid jargon or technical terms that may confuse respondents. Keep sentences and questions concise to minimize cognitive load.

1 + 1

[1] 2
